Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Situation2: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my phone buzzing with a new message from my boyfriend—another tense text about our budget, another round in the argument that had left me exhausted all week. Just as I started to type a reply, my granddaughter wandered in, her eyes uncertain. “Grandma, how do you know when you’re ready for something new?” she asked, her voice small but hopeful. I knew she was on the edge of a big decision, looking to me for the kind of steady wisdom I’d always tried to offer. But my mind was tangled in the unresolved fight with my boyfriend, the pressure to fix things between us pressing on my chest. I wanted to be present for her, to give her the guidance she needed, but the weight of my other life—my other role—kept pulling me away. I could feel both worlds demanding all of me at once, and I didn’t know how to be the wise grandparent she needed while my heart was still caught up in being the girlfriend who had to make things right.
